Description: Fragment of a basin, more specifically sha-basin, carved from dark grey basalt; row of hieroglyphic text crudely incised on one side.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: Sha-basins are ritual basins (Wörterbuch der ägyptischen Sprache vol. IV, 1971, 401, 2) particularly typical of the Ptolemaic period (Yoyotte 1994-95, 674). On this sha-basin, see: Petrie 1886, 34, pl. XXXVI, 5; Gardner 1888, 81, pl. XXIII, 5; Yoyotte 1994-95, 674 (with wrong ref. to Gardner 1888). Two fragments of sha-basin in basalt bearing a demotic inscription were discovered to the north side of the Great Temenos (BM 1885,1101.22 and 1885,1101.23). It is not certain that this fragment stemmed from the same area. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Yoyotte, J. 1994/95, ‘Les contacts entre Égyptiens et Grecs (viie-iie siècles avant J.-C.) : Naucratis, ville égyptienne’, Annuaire du Collège de France, 669-82.
